Collective investment undertakings (UCITS) and marketing communications Collective investment undertakings (UCITS) and marketing communications SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1160 — marketing requirements for collective investment undertakings and on marketing communications addressed to investors WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the transparency and investor protection of collective investment undertakings (UCITS) and marketing communications addressed to investors. It also establishes a central database on the cross-border marketing of AIFs and UCITS. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to: alternative investment fund managers (AIFMs) and UCITS management companies, including any UCITS which has not designated a UCITS management company; European venture capital funds (EurVECA) and European social entrepreneurship funds (EurSEF). The regulation also establishes a central database on the cross-border marketing of AIFs and UCITS. The regulation also establishes a central database on the cross-border marketing of AIFs and UCITS. EU market surveillance: rules and procedures EU market surveillance: rules and procedures SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 — rules and procedures for the market surveillance of products subject to certain EU harmonisation legislation WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules and procedures for the market surveillance of products subject to certain EU harmonisation legislation. It aims to ensure that the EU’s harmonisation legislation is applied correctly. KEY POINTS The regulation covers products that are subject to certain EU harmonisation legislation listed in Annex I concerning manufactured products other than food, feed, medicinal products for human and veterinary use, living plants and animals, products of human origin and products of plants and animals relating directly to their future reproduction. The regulation does not apply to products covered by other EU harmonisation legislation, for example those set out in Regulation (EC) No 1223/2009, (EU) 2017/746 and (EU) 2017/746. Cross-border access to television and radio programmes Cross-border access to television and radio programmes SUMMARY OF: Directive 2019/36/EU — cross-border access to television and radio programmes WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to facilitate cross-border access to a greater number of television and radio programmes by facilitating the clearance of rights for the provision of online services that are ancillary to the broadcast of certain types of television and radio programmes and for the retransmission of television and radio programmes. It also lays down rules for the transmission of television and radio programmes through the process of direct injection. KEY POINTS The directive covers ancillary online services offered by a broadcasting organisation, which have a clear and subordinate relationship with the broadcasting organisation’s broadcasts. These services include services that give access to television and radio programmes in a strictly linear manner, simultaneously to the broadcast, and services that give access, within a defined time period after the broadcast, to television and radio programmes which have been previously broadcast by the broadcasting organisation, so-called ‘catch-up services’. The country of origin principle does not apply to any subsequent communication to the public of works or other protected subject matter, by wire or wireless means, or to any subsequent making available to the public of works or other protected subject matter, by wire or wireless means, in such a way that members of the public may access them from a place and at a time individually chosen by them, or to any subsequent reproduction of the works or other protected subject matter which are contained in the ancillary online service. EU country code top-level domain (ccTLD) EU country code top-level domain (ccTLD) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/96 — implementing the.eu country code top-level domain WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to support the digital single market, to build an online European identity and to encourage cross-border online activities. It lays down the conditions for its implementation, including the designation and characteristics of the registry. KEY POINTS The regulation lays down the eligibility criteria for registering a.eu domain name. The registry is a not-for-profit organisation. It has its registered office, central administration and principal place of business within the EU. The registry is a not-for-profit organisation. It sets out the objectives of the European Community’s multiannual financial framework (MFF) for the period 2021-2027. It also sets out the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding. KEY POINTS The CEF contributes 60 % of its overall financial envelope to climate objectives. Terrorist content online: addressing the misuse of hosting services Terrorist content online: addressing the misuse of hosting services SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/784 on addressing the misuse of hosting services for the dissemination of terrorist content online WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that hosting service providers are able to remove or disable access to terrorist content online in all EU countries. It also aims to facilitate cooperation between EU countries, hosting service providers and Europol. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the procedures and deadlines for removing or disabling access to terrorist content online. It also sets out the procedures for removing or disabling access to terrorist content in all EU countries. The regulation also sets out the procedures for removing or disabling access to terrorist content in all EU countries. The regulation also sets out the procedures for removing or disabling access to terrorist content in all EU countries. The regulation also sets out the procedures for removing or disabling access to terrorist content in all EU countries. EU countries had to incorporate it into national law by 7 June 2022. BACKGROUND For more information, see: ‘Terrorist content online’ on the European Commission’s website. It sets out the rules for the Horizon Europe Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (HFP) 2021-2027. EU Space Programme EU Space Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/695 — the Union Space Programme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Union Space Programme (‘the Programme’) for the duration of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027. It lays down the objectives of the programme, the budget for the period 2021-2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding, as well as the rules for the implementation of the programme. KEY POINTS The programme aims to: ensure efficient and autonomous access to space for the programme; foster an innovative and competitive European space sector, upstream and downstream; strengthen the EU’s space ecosystem and reinforce the Union as a global player. The programme also supports the procurement and aggregation of launching services for the needs of the programme and, at their request, the aggregation for EU countries and international organisations. The programme may provide funding in any of the forms laid down in the Financial Regulation, in particular grants, prizes and procurement. The Commission may reallocate funds between the categories of expenditure referred to in the regulation, up to a ceiling of 7,5 % of the category of expenditure that receives the funds or the category that provides the funds. Actions that receive cumulative funding from different Union programmes must be audited only once, covering all involved programmes and their respective applicable rules. The Commission may reallocate funds between the categories of expenditure referred to in the regulation, up to a ceiling of 7,5 % of the category of expenditure that receives the funds or the category that provides the funds. Digital Europe Programme Digital Europe Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/96 — Digital Europe Programme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Digital Europe Programme (DiRT) for the duration of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027. It aims to support the digital transformation of industry and to foster better exploitation of the industrial potential of policies on innovation, research and technological development, for the benefit of citizens and businesses across the EU, including its outermost regions and its economically disadvantaged regions. KEY POINTS The DIT is a seven-year programme that aims to support the digital transformation of industry and to foster better exploitation of the industrial potential of policies on innovation, research and technological development, for the benefit of citizens and businesses across the EU, including its outermost regions and its economically disadvantaged regions. The DIT is implemented in close coordination with other EU programmes as applicable, and aims to strengthen and promote Europe’s capacities in key digital technology areas through large-scale deployment; in the private sector and in areas of public interest, to widen the diffusion and uptake of Europe’s key digital technologies, promoting the digital transformation and access to digital technologies. It aims to improve the functioning of the internal market, the competitiveness and sustainability of enterprises, especially SMEs, standardisation, market surveillance and consumer protection. It aims to support the development of the EU regulatory framework in the areas of company law and corporate governance, and contract law, with a view to making businesses, especially SMEs, more efficient and competitive, while providing protection for stakeholders affected by company operations, and with a view to reacting to emerging policy challenges. KEY POINTS The programme aims to: improve the functioning of the internal market, the competitiveness and sustainability of enterprises, especially SMEs, standardisation, market surveillance and consumer protection; support the development of the EU regulatory framework in the areas of company law and corporate governance, and contract law, with a view to making businesses, especially SMEs, more efficient and competitive, while providing protection for stakeholders affected by company operations, and with a view to reacting to emerging policy challenges. Reporting obligations for ships reporting obligations for ships SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/96 — harmonised reporting obligations for ships WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to simplify and harmonise reporting obligations for ships arriving in and/or departing from ports of the EU. It aims to improve the efficiency of maritime transport and to limit the duplication of the information which must be provided for operational purposes when a ship makes a port call. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a European Maritime Single Window (EMSWe) which provides one or more categories of the port services listed in Regulation (EU) 2017/352. The EMSWe data set includes: the names and addresses of the ships and their ports; the names and addresses of the ports and their terminals; the names and addresses of the ports and their terminals; the names and addresses of the ports and their terminals; Summary 12:
Electronic road toll systems Electronic road toll systems SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/54 — electronic road toll systems WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to make electronic road toll systems (OBEs) interoperable across the EU. It aims to reduce the cost of, and the burdens linked to, the payment of road fees across the EU. KEY POINTS The directive applies to all electronic road toll systems (OBEs) in the EU. EETS providers must: register their EETS domains in the EU countries; provide EETS users with OBE suitable for use, interoperable and capable of communicating with the relevant electronic road toll systems in service in the EU countries; cooperate with toll chargers in their efforts to identify suspected offenders; provide EETS users with OBE suitable for use with 5,8 GHz microwave technology only, to be used in EETS domains which do not require satellite positioning or mobile communications technologies. The directive does not apply to parking fees. KEY TERMS Electronic road toll system: an electronic system that allows users to pay a road fee by using their vehicle’s registration number. MAIN DOCUMENT Directive (EU) 2019/54 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 February 2019 on the electronic road toll systems (OJ L 81, 2.3.2019, pp. 18–24) Successive amendments to Directive (EU) 2019/54 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. EU security standards for identity cards and residence documents EU security standards for identity cards and residence documents SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1724 — security standards for identity cards and residence documents WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to strengthen the security standards applicable to identity cards and residence documents issued by EU countries to their nationals and to residence documents issued by EU countries to family members who are not nationals of a EU country. It also aims to improve the security of travel documents. KEY POINTS EU countries must issue and renew identity cards and residence documents to their nationals in accordance with national laws. The regulation does not apply to identification documents issued on a provisional basis with a period of validity of less than 6 months. EU countries must issue and renew identity cards and residence documents to their own nationals in accordance with national laws. The regulation does not apply to identification documents issued on a provisional basis with a period of validity of less than 6 months. EU countries must issue and renew residence cards to family members who are not nationals of a EU country and, on application, to issue documents certifying permanent residence and to issue residence cards. The regulation does not apply to identification documents issued on a provisional basis with a period of validity of less than 6 months. EU countries must issue and renew identity cards and residence documents to their own nationals in accordance with national laws. The regulation does not apply to identification documents issued on a provisional basis with a period of validity of less than 6 months. The regulation does not apply to identification documents issued on a provisional basis with a period of validity of less than 6 months. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 2 August 2019. EU countries had to incorporate it into national law by 2 August 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: ‘Identity cards’ on the European Commission's website. Interoperability between EU information systems Interoperability between EU information systems SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/817 establishing a framework for interoperability between EU information systems in the field of borders and visa and amending Regulations (EC) No 767/2008, (EU) 2016/399, (EU) 2017/2226, (EU) 2018/1240, (EU) 2018/1726 and (EU) 2018/1861 of the European Parliament and of the Council and Council Decisions 2004/512/EC and 2008/633/JHA WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a framework for interoperability between EU information systems for security, border and migration management. It aims to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of checks at the external borders, to contribute to prevention and combating illegal immigration and to contribute to a high level of security within the area of freedom, security and justice of the EU. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a European search portal (ESP) and a shared biometric matching service (shared BMS) to facilitate the fast, seamless, efficient, systematic and controlled access of EU authorities and EU agencies to the EU information systems, to Europol data and to the Interpol databases for the performance of their tasks and in accordance with their access rights and the objectives and purposes of the EES, VIS, ETIAS, Eurodac, SIS and ECRIS-TCN. The ESP is a single window or ‘message broker’ to search the various central systems and retrieve the necessary information seamlessly and in full respect of the access control and data protection requirements of the underlying systems. The ESP is a single window or ‘message broker’ to search the various central systems and retrieve the necessary information seamlessly and in full respect of the access control and data protection requirements of the underlying systems. It aims to ensure that all electronic communications networks in the EU can be used effectively and efficiently. It aims to ensure that all consumers have access at an affordable price to an available adequate broadband internet access and voice communications services, at a fixed location. Monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles Monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/2400 — monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the requirements for the monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles registered in the EU. It applies to the following vehicle categories: vehicles of categories M1, M2, N1 and N2 with a reference mass that exceeds 2 610 kg and which do not fall within the scope of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council (13), and all vehicles of categories O3 and O4. The data are to be reported to the European Commission by 28 February each year. The Commission must monitor the results of on-road verification tests to verify the CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles. The Commission must publish an annual report with its analysis of the data transmitted by EU countries and manufacturers for the preceding calendar year. The analysis must indicate, as minimum, the performance of the heavy-duty vehicle fleet of the EU as well as that of each EU country and each manufacturer in terms of the average fuel consumption and CO2 emissions for each heavy-duty vehicle group by mission profile, load and fuel combination. The analysis must also take into account data on the uptake of new and advanced CO2 reducing technologies, as well as of alternative powertrains. The Commission must publish an annual report with its analysis of the data transmitted by EU countries and manufacturers for the preceding calendar year. The Commission must also publish an annual report with its analysis of the data transmitted by EU countries and manufacturers for the preceding calendar year. Energy labelling Energy labelling SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/30 — energy labelling WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down a framework for energy labelling, allowing customers to choose more efficient products. It aims to improve the efficiency of energy-related products through informed customer choice and harmonising related requirements at EU level benefits also manufacturers, industry and the EU economy overall. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the general obligations of suppliers and dealers in relation to the product database. The supplier must ensure that products that are placed on the market are accompanied, for each individual unit, free of charge, with accurate printed labels and with product information sheets. The supplier must ensure the accuracy of the labels and product information sheets that it provides and produce technical documentation sufficient to enable the accuracy to be assessed. Dealers must display the label provided by the supplier or made available in accordance with the relevant delegated act. The dealer must make available to customers the product information sheet, including, upon request, in physical form at the point of sale. The supplier must ensure the accuracy of the labels and product information sheets that it provides and produce technical documentation sufficient to enable the accuracy to be assessed. The supplier must inform the customer of the objective of the update and of the changes in the parameters, including any change in the label class. Protection of personal data Protection of personal data SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/680 — protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that the free movement of personal data within the EU is not restricted or prohibited for reasons connected with the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data. It lays down rules on the protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to the processing of personal data by the EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. It does not apply to the processing of personal data by public authorities. However, public authorities which may receive personal data in the framework of a particular inquiry in accordance with EU or Member State law may not be regarded as recipients. However, public authorities which may receive personal data in the framework of a particular inquiry in accordance with EU or Member State law shall not be regarded as recipients. The regulation also applies to the processing of personal data by public authorities in the performance of their tasks. The regulation also provides for the establishment of a European Data Protection Board (EDPB) to ensure consistent application and enforcement of the regulation throughout the EU. The regulation also provides for the possibility for transfers of personal data to third countries and international organisations. The regulation also provides for the possibility for the processing of genetic data, biometric data and data concerning health. The regulation also provides for the right to object and automated individual decision-making. The regulation also provides for the right to compensation and liability. The regulation also provides for the establishment of a European Data Protection Board (EDPB) to ensure consistent application and enforcement of the regulation throughout the EU. The regulation also provides for the possibility for the processing of special categories of personal data (‘sensitive data’). Harmonised consumer prices and the house price index Harmonised consumer prices and the house price index SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/17 — harmonised indices of consumer prices and the house price index WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP, HICP-CT, OOH price index) and of the house price index (HPI) at EU and national level. It aims to improve the relevance and comparability of the HICP and the HICP-CT. KEY POINTS The HICP and the HICP-CT are based on the price changes and weights of products included in the household final monetary consumption expenditure. The HICP and the HICP-CT are broken down into categories of the European classification of individual consumption according to purpose (ECOICOP). The ECOICOP is consistent with the United Nations Convention on the Functioning of the European Union (UNCOICOP). The HICP and the HICP-CT are broken down into categories of the European classification of individual consumption according to purpose (ECOICOP). The ECOICOP is aligned with the UN COICOP. It sets out rules for implementing the EU’s anti-dumping rules. It sets out the conditions for imposing anti-dumping duties on imports of a product from all sources found to be dumped and causing injury. Summary 24:
Countervailing measures: EU rules on countervailing measures Countervailing measures: EU rules on countervailing measures SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 216/2016 — rules on countervailing measures WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules on countervailing measures (also known as ‘countervailing duties’) to offset any subsidies granted, directly or indirectly, for the manufacture, production, export or transport of any product whose release for free circulation in the EU causes injury. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the rules for determining whether a subsidy is a subsidy. It defines the conditions under which a subsidy is to be imposed. It also sets out the procedures for the rejection of complaints and the initiation of investigations. The regulation also sets out the rules for the accelerated review of the measures. The regulation also sets out the procedures for the accelerated review of the measures. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2016. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Countervailing measures (European Commission). KEY TERMS Countervailing measures: subsidies granted to a firm or an industry contingent upon export performance. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) No 216/2016 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 May 2016 on rules on countervailing measures (OJ L 216, 21.7.2016, pp. 1-2) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) No 216/2016 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Recovery and resilience facility Recovery and resilience facility SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1725 — recovery and resilience facility WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules and procedures for the establishment of a recovery and resilience facility (RFF) to support the recovery in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis. It aims to improve the resilience, crisis preparedness, adjustment capacity and growth potential of the EU countries. KEY POINTS The RFF is designed to help EU countries prepare and implement reforms and public investments to address the challenges identified in the context of the European Semester. The RFF is based on the six pillars of the EU’s economic, social and territorial cohesion: the six pillars are: the economic, social and territorial cohesion; the six pillars are: the economic, social and territorial cohesion; Summary 26:
Structural Reform Support Programme Structural Reform Support Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/825 — technical support for EU countries in the implementation of reforms WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a technical support instrument to support EU countries in the implementation of reforms. It aims to encourage investment, increase competitiveness and achieve sustainable economic and social convergence, resilience and recovery. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a technical support instrument to support EU countries in the implementation of reforms. It aims to encourage investment, increase competitiveness and achieve sustainable economic and social convergence, resilience and recovery. It also aims to strengthen the institutional and administrative capacity of EU countries to facilitate socially inclusive, green and digital transitions. The regulation also lays down the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding. The regulation sets out the general objective and specific objectives of the instrument, the budget of the instrument for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding. The regulation also sets out the forms of EU funding for actions under the instrument, including grants, public procurement contracts, reimbursement of costs incurred by external experts, contributions to trust funds set up by international organisations and actions carried out through indirect management. The regulation also sets out the monitoring of implementation and measures to be achieved. The Commission must monitor the implementation of the instrument and measure the achievement of the general objective and specific objectives. The Commission must also provide an independent mid-term evaluation report on the implementation of the regulation by 20 February 2025. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Structural Reform Support Programme (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2017/825 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 May 2017 on the establishment of the Structural Reform Support Programme for the period 2017 to 2020 and amending Regulations (EU) No 1303/2013 and (EU) No 1305/2013 (OJ L 129, 19.5.2017, pp. 132–142) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2017/825 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Rail passengers’ rights and obligations Rail passengers’ rights and obligations SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1832/2018 — rights and obligations for rail passengers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the rights of rail passengers and to ensure that they receive the same information as other citizens. It aims to improve the quality and effectiveness of rail passenger services. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to international and domestic rail journeys and services throughout the EU provided by one or more railway undertakings licensed in accordance with Directive 2012/34/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council. It does not apply to urban, suburban and regional rail passenger services; international rail passenger services of which a significant part, including at least one scheduled station stop, is operated outside the EU. Enlargement of the EU: Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) Enlargement of the EU: Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/947 — Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the objectives of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) for the period of the multiannual financial framework 2021-2027 (‘2021-2027 MFF’). It lays down the objectives of IPA III, the budget for the 2021-2027 period, the forms of Union assistance and the rules for providing such assistance. KEY POINTS The Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is based on a performance-based approach and the fair share principle. It is designed to help the beneficiaries listed in Annex I to the regulation to: reform their political, legal and economic systems with a view to EU membership; promote good neighbourly relations, fostering Union integration and promoting socioeconomic development; protect the environment and promoting adaptation to climate change, the mitigation of climate change and risk prevention and management; prom. The Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is based on a performance-based approach and the fair share principle. It is designed to help the beneficiaries listed in Annex I to the regulation to: reform their political, legal and economic systems with a view to EU membership; promote good neighbourly relations, fostering Union integration and promoting socioeconomic development; protect the environment and promoting adaptation to climate change, the mitigation of climate change and risk prevention and management; prom. The Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA III) is based on a performance-based approach and the fair share principle. Reporting by whistleblowers Reporting by whistleblowers SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/1371 — protection of whistleblowers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to enhance the enforcement of EU law and policies in specific areas by laying down common minimum standards providing for a high level of protection of persons reporting breaches of EU law. KEY POINTS Reporting by whistleblowers The directive lays down minimum standards for reporting breaches of EU law, including breaches of EU competition and State aid rules, as well as breaches relating to the internal market in relation to acts which breach the rules of corporate tax or to arrangements the purpose of which is to obtain a tax advantage that defeats the object or purpose of the applicable corporate tax law. The directive also lays down minimum standards for breaches relating to the internal market, including breaches of EU competition and State aid rules, as well as breaches relating to the internal market in relation to acts which breach the rules of corporate tax or to arrangements the purpose of which is to obtain a tax advantage that defeats the object or purpose of the applicable corporate tax law. European Border and Coast Guard European Border and Coast Guard SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/96 — European Border and Coast Guard SUMMARY WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO? It aims to improve the efficiency of the EU return policy by ensuring that the EU’s external borders are managed efficiently in full compliance with fundamental rights and to increase the effectiveness of the EU return policy. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes the European Border and Coast Guard (EFCA) as a shared responsibility of the EU’s Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the EU. It sets out the definition and calculation of gross national income at market prices (GNI) and gross domestic product at market prices (GDP) in the context of national accounts compilation. It repeals Directive 89/130/EEC, Euratom and Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1287/2003. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the definition and calculation of GNI and GDP in the context of national accounts compilation. European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2019/1728 — European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the conditions and procedures enabling the EU to provide financial assistance to a Member State which is experiencing, or is seriously threatened with, a severe economic disturbance caused by the COVID-19 outbreak. The instrument complements the national measures taken by affected Member States by providing financial assistance to help those Member States cope with the sudden and severe increase in actual and possibly also planned public expenditure intended to mitigate the direct economic, social and health-related effects of the exceptional occurrence caused by the COVID-19 outbreak. The instrument complements the national measures taken by affected Member States by providing financial assistance to help those Member States cope with the sudden and severe increase in actual and possibly also planned public expenditure intended to mitigate the direct economic, social and health-related effects of the exceptional occurrence caused by the COVID-19 outbreak. It sets out the rules for the recovery and resolution of central counterparties (CCPs)*. European Security and Defence College European Security and Defence College SUMMARY OF: Decision (CFSP) 2016/2382 — European Security and Defence College WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It establishes the European Security and Defence College (ESDC) to provide training and education in the field of the Union’s Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) in the wider context of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) at European level. KEY POINTS The ESDC is organised as a network bringing together civilian and military institutes, colleges, academies, universities, institutions, centres of excellence and other actors dealing with security and defence policy issues within the EU as identified by Member States, as well as the European Union Institute for Security Studies (EUISS). The ESDC establishes close links with the EU institutions and relevant Union agencies, in particular with the EU Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL), the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (FRONTEX), the European Defence Agency (EDA), the European Satellite Centre (EU SatCen) and the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol). The ESDC is responsible for: organising and conducting ESDC training and education activities in the field of the EU’s Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) in the wider context of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) at European level; identifying and disseminating best practices in relation to various CSDP and CSDP, issues through its training and education activities; helping promote professional relations and contacts among training and education participants. The ESDC is composed of one representative appointed by each Member State and is the decision-making body of the ESDC. The ESDC is composed of: a steering committee composed of one representative appointed by each Member State and is the decision-making body of the ESDC; a board composed of senior representatives from those civilian and military institutes and other actors identified by Member States to support the conduct of ESDC training and education activities and of the Director of EUISS or the Director’s representative. Card-based payment transactions and internet and mobile payments based on cards Card-based payment transactions and internet and mobile payments based on cards SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 — technical and business requirements for card-based payment transactions and internet and mobile payments based on cards WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down uniform technical and business requirements for card-based payment transactions carried out within the EU, where both the payer’s payment service provider and the payee’s payment service provider are located therein. Transparency of skills and qualifications Transparency of skills and qualifications SUMMARY OF: Decision No 2241/2004/EC on a single Community framework for the transparency of qualifications and competences (Europass) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It establishes a European framework to support the transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications acquired in formal, non-formal and informal settings, including through practical experiences, mobility and volunteering. It replaces Decision No 2241/2004/EC, which established a framework to address the challenges relating to job seeking, engaging in learning and career management. KEY POINTS The decision establishes a European framework to support the transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications acquired in formal, non-formal and informal settings, including through practical experiences, mobility and volunteering. It consists of web-based tools and relevant available information, including information to support the European dimension of guidance provided through an online platform and supported by national services intended to help users to better communicate and present skills and qualifications and to compare qualifications. The use of Europass tools for the assessment of skills and self-assessment of skills is not directly to formal recognition or the issuance of qualifications. Statistics on inland waterways Statistics on inland waterways SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/1796 — statistics on goods transport by inland waterways WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes common rules for the production of European statistics concerning inland waterways transport. It aims to ensure that the European Commission (Eurostat) can collect and disseminate statistics on goods transport by inland waterways. KEY POINTS The regulation does not apply to: the carriage of goods by vessels of less than 50 deadweight tonnes; vessels used principally for the carriage of passengers; vessels used for ferrying purposes; vessels used solely for non-commercial purposes by port administrations and public authorities; vessels used solely for bunkering or storage; vessels not used for the carriage of goods such as fishery vessels, dredgers, floating workshops, houseboats and pleasure craft. Summary 48:
Statistics on rail transport Statistics on rail transport SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/17 — common rules for the production of rail transport statistics WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to establish common rules for the production of rail transport statistics. It aims to ensure that the data collected are comparable across the EU. KEY POINTS The regulation covers all railways in the EU. Each EU country must report statistics which relate to rail transport on its national territory. Where a railway undertaking operates in more than one EU country, the national authorities concerned must require the undertaking to provide data separately for each country in which it operates so as to enable national statistics to be compiled. The regulation also covers: annual statistics on goods transport; quarterly statistics on goods and passenger transport; regional statistics on goods and passenger transport; statistics on traffic flows on the rail network. The regulation also sets out the rules for the transmission of statistics to Eurostat. The Commission adopts implementing acts laying down the arrangements for the transmission of the statistics and the arrangements for the dissemination of results. The Commission adopts implementing acts specifying the detailed arrangements, structure, periodicity and comparability elements for the standard quality reports. The Commission must submit a report to the European Parliament and to the Council on the implementation of this regulation and on future developments. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 13 December 2018. BACKGROUND For more information, see: ‘Railway statistics’ on the European Commission's website. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2018/17 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 December 2018 on common rules for the production of rail transport statistics (OJ L 202, 21.3.2018, pp. 1-2) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2018/17 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. RELATED DOCUMENTS Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2017/17 of 11 March 2017 on the transmission of data subject to statistical confidentiality to the Statistical Office of the European Communities, Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1101/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the transmission of data subject to statistical confidentiality to the Statistical Office of the European Communities, Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 322/97 on Community Statistics, and Council Decision 89/382/EEC, Euratom establishing a Committee on the Statistical Programmes of the European Communities (OJ L 202, 21.3.2017, pp. 1-2) See consolidated version. last update 04.02.2021

Visas for non-EU nationals Visas for non-EU nationals SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1833/2018 — visas for non-EU nationals WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for visas for non-EU nationals travelling to the EU’s external borders. It lays down the rules for the temporary suspension of the visa requirement for non-EU nationals travelling to the EU’s external borders. KEY POINTS The regulation lists the non-EU countries whose nationals must be in possession of a visa when crossing the external borders of the EU countries. The list includes: countries that are not recognised as countries by at least one EU country; countries that are not members of the armed forces travelling on North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) or Partnership for Peace business. Recovery plan for bluefin tuna Recovery plan for bluefin tuna SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/17 — general rules for the application by the European Union of the recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the general rules for the application by the European Union (EU) of the recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. KEY POINTS The EU has a bluefin tuna quota, which is set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). The quota is based on the best catch rates per vessel and gear estimated by the Standing Committee on Research and Statistics of the International Convention for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT). Shipbuilding injurious pricing Shipbuilding injurious pricing SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/1036 — protection against injurious pricing of vessels WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to protect the EU’s shipbuilding industry against the sale of vessels below their normal value which cause injury. It lays down procedural and substantive conditions for lodging a complaint against injurious pricing. It also sets out the procedures for the rejection of a complaint and the initiation of proceedings. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the rules for the imposition of an injurious pricing charge on the builder of any injuriously priced vessel whose sale to a buyer other than a buyer of the country in which the vessel originates. The normal value is based on the price paid or payable, in the ordinary course of trade, for a like vessel by an independent buyer in the exporting country. In determining whether such substantial comparability exists, the following factors must be considered: the terms and circumstances of the transaction; commercial practice within the benefit from the operation of the vessel. Cableway installations: safety requirements Cableway installations: safety requirements SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1025/2012 on European standardisation, amending Council Directives 89/686/EEC and 93/15/EEC and Directives 94/9/EC, 94/25/EC, 95/16/EC, 97/23/EC, 98/34/EC, 2004/22/EC, 2007/23/EC, 2009/23/EC and 2009/105/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Council Decision 87/95/EEC and Decision No 1673/2006/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that cableway installations comply with the essential requirements of Directive 2000/9/EC. It also lays down rules on the entry into service of new installations designed to transport persons, to modifications of cableway installations requiring a new authorisation and to subsystems and safety components for cableway installations. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to new cableway installations designed to transport persons, to modifications of cableway installations requiring a new authorisation and to subsystems and safety components for cableway installations. The person responsible for the cableway installation, determined by a EU country in accordance with national law, must carry out a safety analysis of the planned cableway installation or have such a safety analysis carried out. The safety report must include the results of the safety analysis and the reasons for the safety analysis. The manufacturer must draw up an EU declaration of conformity and affix the CE marking. Importers must ensure that the manufacturer has drawn up the technical documentation, that the subsystem or safety component bears the CE marking and that it is accompanied by a copy of the EU declaration of conformity, by instructions and safety information, and, where appropriate, by other required documents, and that the manufacturer has complied with the requirements set out in Annex II. Manufacturers must keep distributors informed of any monitoring of the safety of their subsystems or safety components. Accessibility of electronic communications services Accessibility of electronic communications services SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/54 — accessibility requirements for electronic communications services WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to ensure that all EU citizens, regardless of their abilities, can access electronic communications services, including audiovisual media services, and other facilities and services open or provided to the public, both in urban and in rural areas. KEY POINTS The directive applies to electronic communications services, including audiovisual media services, and to air, bus, rail and waterborne passenger transport services, except for urban, suburban and regional transport services. The directive also applies to websites, mobile device-based services, and answering emergency communications to the single European emergency number ‘112’. The directive also applies to the following services provided to consumers after 28 June 2025: electronic communications services with the exception of transmission services used for the provision of machine-to-machine services; services providing access to audiovisual media services; the following elements of air, bus, rail and waterborne passenger transport services, except for urban, suburban and regional transport services for which only the elements under point (v) apply: websites; mobile device-based services including answering emergency communications to the single European emergency number ‘112’. The directive also applies to the following services provided to consumers after 28 June 2025: electronic communications services with the exception of transmission services used for the provision of machine-to-machine services; services providing access to audiovisual media services; the following elements of air, bus, rail and waterborne passenger transport services, except for urban, suburban and regional transport services for which only the elements under point (v) apply: websites; mobile device-based services including answering emergency communications to the single European emergency number ‘112’. The directive also applies to the following services provided to consumers after 28 June 2025: electronic communications services with the exception of transmission services used for the provision of machine-to-machine services; services providing access to audiovisual media services; the following elements of air, bus, rail and waterborne passenger transport services, except for urban, suburban and regional transport services for which only the elements under point (v) apply: websites; mobile device-based services including answering emergency communications to the single European emergency number ‘112’. The directive also applies to the following services provided to consumers after 28 June 2025: electronic communications services with the exception of transmission services used for the provision of machine-to-machine services; services providing access to audiovisual media services; the following elements of air, bus, rail and waterborne passenger transport services, except for urban, suburban and regional transport services for which only the elements under point (v) apply: websites; mobile device-based services including answering emergency communications to the single European emergency number ‘112’. The directive also applies to the following services provided to consumers after 28 June 2025: electronic communications services with the exception of transmission services used for the provision of machine-to-machine services; services providing access to audiovisual media services; the following elements of air, bus, rail and waterborne passenger transport services, except for urban, suburban and regional transport services for which only the elements under point (v) apply: websites; mobile device-based services including answering emergency communications to the single European emergency number ‘112’. It establishes a Union system for supply chain due diligence (‘Union system’) to ensure that the vast majority of minerals and metals falling within the scope of this regulation are subject to its obligations. It also lays down the rules for implementing the regulation. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to minerals and metals containing or consisting of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold. The regulation does not apply to recycled metals. The regulation does not apply to stocks where a Union importer demonstrates that those stocks were created in the current form on a verifiable date prior to 1 February 2013. Management system obligations The regulation requires importers to: adopt, and clearly communicate to suppliers and the public up-to-date information on, their supply chain policy for the minerals and metals potentially originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas; incorporate in their supply chain policy standards against which supply chain due diligence is to be conducted consistent with the standards set out in the regulation. Customs programme for cooperation in the field of customs Customs programme for cooperation in the field of customs SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/21 establishing a programme for cooperation in the field of customs WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a programme for cooperation in the field of customs for the period 2021-2027. The programme is designed to support the customs union and customs authorities working together and acting as one to protect the financial and economic interests of the EU and its Member States, to ensure security and safety within the EU and to protect the Union from unfair and illegal trade, while facilitating legitimate business activity. The programme is implemented under direct management in accordance with the Financial Regulation (EU) 2018/1046. The programme may provide funding in any of the forms laid down in the Financial Regulation, in particular by means of grants, prizes, procurement and the reimbursement of travel and subsistence expenses incurred by external experts. The programme may also provide funding in any of the forms laid down in the Financial Regulation, in particular by means of grants, prizes, procurement and the reimbursement of travel and subsistence expenses incurred by external experts. The programme may finance up to 100 % of the total eligible costs of an action. Recovery Instrument Recovery Instrument SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2018/1046 — European Union Recovery Instrument WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Union Recovery Instrument (ERI) to support the recovery of the economy and employment in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis. It aims to ensure a sustainable and resilient recovery throughout the EU and facilitate the implementation of economic support, the established mechanisms of spending through and support for agriculture and development in rural areas in addressing the impact of the COVID-19 crisis. Summary 66:
Sanctions for enhancing the enforcement of the Stability and Growth Pact Sanctions for enhancing the enforcement of the Stability and Growth Pact SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1143/2011 — sanctions for enhancing the enforcement of the Stability and Growth Pact WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out a system of sanctions for enhancing the enforcement of the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP) in the euro area. It aims to ensure that the EU’s economic and monetary union (EU) is functioning properly. KEY POINTS Sanctions The regulation sets out a system of sanctions for enhancing the enforcement of the SGP in the euro area. It aims to ensure that the EU’s economic and monetary union (EU) is functioning properly. The sanctions are based on the SGP and the complete economic governance framework. The sanctions are of an administrative nature. The interest earned by the Commission on deposits lodged with the Commission and the fines collected are assigned to the European Financial Stability Facility. The Commission may decide to impose a fine on a Member State that intentionally or by serious negligence misrepresents deficit and debt data relevant for the application of Articles 121 or 126 TFEU or for the application of the Protocol on the excessive deficit procedure annexed to the TEU and to the TFEU. The Commission may conduct all investigations necessary to establish the existence of the misrepresentations. The Commission may decide to initiate an investigation when it finds that there are serious indications of the existence of facts liable to constitute such a misrepresentation. The Commission may also decide to initiate an investigation when it finds that there are serious indications of the existence of facts liable to constitute such a misrepresentation. The Court of Justice of the European Union has unlimited jurisdiction to review the decisions of the Council imposing fines under Articles 121 or 126 TFEU or for the application of the Protocol on the excessive deficit procedure annexed to the TEU and to the TFEU. The Commission may adopt delegated acts in accordance with: detailed criteria establishing the amount of the fine; detailed rules concerning the procedures for the investigations referred to in paragraph 3, the associated measures and the reporting on the investigations; detailed rules of procedure aimed at guaranteeing the rights of the defence, access to the file, legal representation, confidentiality and provisions as to timing and the collection of the fines. Summary 67:
Statistics on population and housing Statistics on population and housing SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 962/2008 on the decennial provision of comprehensive data on population and housing WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes common rules for the decennial provision of comprehensive data on population and housing. It aims to ensure that the data provided by the EU countries and for reliable overviews to be drawn up at EU level are comparable and comprehensive. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the criteria for the decennial provision of comprehensive data on population and housing. The following persons alone are considered to be usual residents of the geographical area in question: those who have lived in their place of usual residence for a continuous period of at least 12 months before the reference date; or those who arrived in their place of usual residence during the 12 months before the reference date with the intention of staying there for at least one year. The European Commission (Eurostat) must adopt a programme of the statistical data and the metadata to be transmitted to fulfil the requirements of this regulation. The Commission must assess the quality of the data transmitted. The Commission must provide methodological recommendations designed to ensure the quality of the data and metadata produced, acknowledging, in particular, the Conference of European Statisticians Recommendations for the 2010 Censuses of Population and Housing. The Commission must adopt a programme of the statistical data and the metadata to be transmitted to fulfil the requirements of this regulation. The Commission must assess the quality of the data transmitted. The Commission must provide methodological recommendations designed to ensure the quality of the data and metadata produced, acknowledging, in particular, the Conference of European Statisticians Recommendations for the 2010 Censuses of Population and Housing. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 20 June 2008. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Statistics on population and housing (European Commission). This consolidated version is of documentary value only. European Data Protection Supervisor European Data Protection Supervisor SUMMARY OF: Decision (EU) 2018/1725 — European Data Protection Supervisor WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It establishes the European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) to ensure that the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, and in particular their right to data protection, are respected by the EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. KEY POINTS The EDPS is responsible for ensuring that the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, and in particular their right to data protection, are respected by the EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. The EDPS is assisted by a secretariat and lays down a number of provisions concerning staff and budgetary matters. Labelling of tyres Labelling of tyres SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 — labelling of tyres WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for the labelling of tyres, allowing end-users to make an informed choice when purchasing tyres. It also lays down the rules for the monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions from and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to C1 tyres, C2 tyres and C3 tyres. It does not apply to: offroad professional tyres; tyres designed to be fitted only on vehicles registered for the first time before 1 October 1990; tyres whose speed rating is less than 80 km/h; tyres whose nominal rim diameter does not exceed 254 mm or is 635 mm or more; tyres fitted with additional devices to improve traction properties, such as studded tyres; secondhand tyres, unless such tyres are imported from a third country. The regulation also sets out the rules for the monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions from and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles. The regulation repeals Regulation (EC) No 1222/2009. It replaces Regulation (EC) No 661/2009 with effect from 1 May 2021. KEY TERMS Tyres: tyres that are placed on the market by the same supplier as another tyre type with a different tyre type identifier and which has the same technical characteristics that are relevant to the tyre label and the same product information sheet. The regulation does not apply to: offroad professional tyres; tyres designed to be fitted only on vehicles registered for the first time before 1 October 1990; tyres whose speed rating is less than 80 km/h; tyres whose nominal rim diameter does not exceed 254 mm or is 635 mm or more; tyres fitted with additional devices to improve traction properties, such as studded tyres; secondhand tyres, unless such tyres are imported from a third country. Summary 72:
Customs control equipment Customs control equipment SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1896 establishing an Instrument for Financial Support for Border Management and Visa Policy WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes an Instrument for Financial Support for Border Management and Visa Policy (IBSP) to support the customs union and customs authorities in their mission to protect the financial and economic interests of the EU and its Member States, to ensure security and safety within the EU and to protect the Union from illegal trade while facilitating legitimate business activity. KEY POINTS The IBSP is a comprehensive framework for EU financial support in the field of border management, consisting of the Instrument for financial support for customs control equipment (IBSP) established by this regulation and the Instrument for Financial Support for Border Management and Visa Policy established by the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing, as part of the Integrated Border Management Fund, the Instrument for Financial Support for Border Management and Visa Policy. Electricity market: rules for consumers Electricity market: rules for consumers SUMMARY OF: Directive 2019/943 on the internal market for electricity WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to create a fully operational internal market for electricity. It aims to ensure affordable, transparent energy prices and costs for consumers, a high degree of security of supply and a smooth transition towards a sustainable low-carbon energy system. KEY POINTS The directive lays down rules for the organisation and functioning of the EU electricity sector, in particular rules on consumer empowerment and protection, on open access to the integrated market, on third-party access to transmission and distribution infrastructure, unbundling requirements and rules on the independence of regulatory authorities in the EU. European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/694 establishing the European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking (EuroHPC Joint Undertaking) to develop, deploy, extend and maintain in the EU an integrated world-class supercomputing and data infrastructure and to develop and support a highly competitive and innovative High Performance Computing ecosystem. It is open to new members. Climate neutrality in the EU by 2050 Climate neutrality in the EU by 2050 SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/50 — achieving a climate-neutral EU by 2050 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out a framework for the irreversible and gradual reduction of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions by sources and enhancement of removals by sinks regulated in EU law. It also sets out a binding EU-wide climate target for 2040. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out a binding EU-wide climate target for 2040. It aims to achieve a balance between anthropogenic economy-wide emissions by sources and removals by sinks of the greenhouse gases listed in Part 2 of Annex V to Regulation (EU) 2018/1999. The EU-wide target is a domestic reduction of net greenhouse gas emissions (emissions after deduction of removals) by at least 55 % compared to 1990 levels by 2030. The EU-wide target is a domestic reduction of net greenhouse gas emissions (emissions after deduction of removals) by at least 55 % compared to 1990 levels by 2030. EU4Health Programme EU4Health Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/707 — EU4Health Programme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the EU4Health Programme (EU4Health) for the period 2021-2027. It aims to improve human health throughout the EU and to ensure a high level of protection of human health in all EU policies and activities. KEY POINTS The programme is designed to improve health throughout the EU and to ensure a high level of protection of human health in all EU policies and activities. Creative Europe Programme Creative Europe Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1796 establishing the Creative Europe Programme for the period from 2021 to 2027 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Creative Europe Programme (CEP) for the period from 2021 to 2027. It lays down the objectives of the programme, the budget for the period from 2021 to 2027, the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding. KEY POINTS The CEP covers the following strands: the culture strand, which covers cultural and creative sectors with the exception of the audiovisual sector; the media strand, which covers the audiovisual sector; the cross-sectoral strand, which covers actions across all cultural and creative sectors. European Institute of Innovation and Technology European Institute of Innovation and Technology SUMMARY OF: Decision No 1312/2013/EU on the Strategic Innovation Agenda of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT): the contribution of the EIT to a more innovative Europe WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It sets out the priorities and strategy for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) for 2021-2027. It establishes the EIT’s key actions and includes an assessment of the EIT’s expected social, economic and environmental impact, its outreach activities and its capacity to generate best innovation added-value. KEY POINTS The EIT’s priorities are to: increase the openness, impact and transparency of the KICs and the integration of the knowledge triangle across the EU; increase the entrepreneurial and innovation capacity of higher education across Europe by promoting and supporting institutional change in HEIs and the integration of HEIs in innovation ecosystems; increase the regional and local outreach of the EIT and the KICs, in particular by including a wider range of stakeholders in order to address disparities in innovation capacity and to enhance knowledge and innovation diffusion across the EU. The EIT’s specific objectives for 2021-2027 are to: increase the openness, impact and transparency of the KICs and the integration of the knowledge triangle across the EU; increase the entrepreneurial and innovation capacity of higher education across Europe by promoting and supporting institutional change in HEIs and the integration of HEIs in innovation ecosystems; increase the regional and local outreach of the EIT and the KICs, in particular by including a wider range of stakeholders in order to address disparities in innovation capacity and to enhance knowledge and innovation diffusion across the EU. KEY TERMS Geographical indication: an indication which identifies an aromatised wine product as originating in a region, a specific place, or a country, where a given quality, reputation or other characteristics of that product is essentially attributable to its geographical origin. Emergency macro-financial assistance to Ukraine Emergency macro-financial assistance to Ukraine SUMMARY OF: Decision (EU) 2020/701 on providing macro-financial assistance to enlargement and neighbourhood partners in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic Decision (EU) 2020/701 on providing macro-financial assistance to enlargement and neighbourhood partners in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It sets out the EU’s (EU) macro-financial assistance programme for Ukraine. It is based on a quantitative assessment of Ukraine’s residual external financing needs. The assistance is subject to the approval of the EU budget for the relevant year by the European Parliament and the Council. The assistance contributes to covering Ukraine’s balance-of-payments needs as identified in the IMF programme. The assistance is made available by the Commission in two equal instalments, each of which consist of a loan. The amounts of the assistance provided in the form of loans are provisioned, where required, in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2021/947. The Commission must verify, at regular intervals, that the conditions referred to in the MOU continue to be met, including whether the economic policies of Ukraine are in accordance with the objectives of the assistance. The Commission must also coordinate closely with the IMF and the World Bank, and, where necessary, with the European Parliament and with the Council. The Commission must submit to the European Parliament and to the Council a report on the implementation of this decision in the preceding year, including an evaluation of that implementation. FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY? It has applied since 16 November 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Emergency macro-financial assistance to Ukraine (European Commission). It lays down general rules for the implementation by the European Union (EU) of a multiannual recovery plan for swordfish (Xiphias gladius) in the Mediterranean Sea (‘Mediterranean swordfish’). It covers the period 2017–2031, and is binding on the EU. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the management measures, technical conservation measures and control measures for the implementation of the ICCAT recovery plan. The EU and EU countries must ensure that the fishing effort of fishing vessels flying their flag is commensurate with the fishing opportunities for Mediterranean swordfish available to them. The carrying-over of any unused quota for Mediterranean swordfish is prohibited. The EU and EU countries must endeavour to allocate any increase in fishing opportunities resulting from the successful implementation of the regulation to fishing vessels to which no quota for Mediterranean swordfish has previously been allocated and that fulfil the criteria for the allocation of fishing opportunities set out in Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013. European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/2027 establishing the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the priorities of the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF) and the specific rules for providing EU funding. It complements the general rules applicable to the EMFAF under Regulation (EU) 2021/1060. KEY POINTS The EMFAF is a key enabler for sustainable fisheries and the conservation of marine biological resources, for food security through the supply of seafood products, for the growth of a sustainable blue economy and for healthy, safe, secure, clean and sustainably managed seas and oceans. It supports the following priorities: fostering sustainable fisheries and the restoration and conservation of aquatic biological resources; fostering sustainable aquaculture activities, and processing and marketing of fishery and aquaculture products, thus contributing to food security in the EU; enabling a sustainable blue economy in coastal, island and inland areas, and fostering the development of fishing and aquaculture communities; strengthening international ocean governance and enabling seas and oceans to be safe, secure, clean and sustainably managed. Conservation and management measures for tropical tunas Conservation and management measures for tropical tunas SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/2411 — conservation and management measures for tropical tunas WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the conservation and management measures for tropical tunas (tunas that are highly migratory) in the Pacific Ocean. It lays down the rules for the conservation and management of the fishery resources in the area covered by the Convention. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to: purse seine vessels for tropical tunas; elasmobranch species; oceanic whitetip sharks; mobulid rays; silky sharks; longline vessels that fish for species covered by the Convention; other species; seabirds; longline vessels that use hydraulic, mechanical or electrical systems and that fish for species covered by the Convention; scientific observers on longline vessels; scientific observers on longline vessels; data and statistical document; regional vessel register; data and statistical document; confidentiality of electronic reports and messages transmitted to and received from the IATTC Secretariat; and the turtle mortality guidelines. Citizens’ initiative: procedures and conditions Citizens’ initiative: procedures and conditions SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 on the procedures and conditions for a citizens’ initiative WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to encourage participation by citizens in the European Union (EU) by allowing them to submit a proposal for a legal act of the EU for the purpose of implementing the Treaties. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the procedures and conditions for a citizens’ initiative. It invites the Commission to submit a proposal for a legal act of the EU for the purpose of implementing the Treaties. The proposal must be submitted to the Commission within 3 months of the date of registration of the initiative. The organisers must register the initiative with the Commission, providing the information set out in Annex II, in particular on the subject matter and objectives of the initiative. The organisers must designate one representative and one substitute (‘the contact persons’) who liaise between the citizens’ committee and the institutions of the Union throughout the procedure and who must be mandated to speak and act on behalf of the citizens’ committee. The organisers may withdraw a proposed citizens’ initiative of a period of 2 years from the date of registration of the initiative. The organisers may submit the initiative to the Commission, accompanied by information regarding any support and funding received for that initiative. The organisers must submit the initiative to the Commission, accompanied by information regarding any support and funding received for that initiative. The organisers must submit the initiative to the Commission, accompanied by information regarding any support and funding received for that initiative. The organisers must submit the initiative to the Commission, accompanied by information regarding any support and funding received for that initiative. The organisers must submit the initiative to the Commission, accompanied by information regarding any support and funding received for that initiative. The organisers must submit the initiative to the Commission, accompanied by information regarding any support and funding received for that initiative. The organisers must submit the initiative to the Commission, accompanied by information regarding any support and funding received for that initiative. Liability Organisers must be liable for any damage they cause in the organisation of a citizens’ initiative in accordance with applicable national law. The organisers must ensure that personal data collected for a given citizen’s initiative are not used for any purpose other than their indicated support for that initiative. The organisers must destroy all statements of support received for that initiative and any copies thereof at the latest one month after submitting that initiative to the Commission in accordance with Article 9 or 18 months after the date of registration of the proposed citizens’ initiative, whichever is the earlier. The organisers must implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to protect personal data against accidental or unlawful destruction or accidental loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure or access, in particular where the processing involves the transmission of data over a network and against all other unlawful forms of processing. Plant protection products Plant protection products SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 91/414/EEC — plant protection products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that plant protection products do not have any harmful effect on human or animal health or the environment. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to substances, including micro-organisms having general or specific action against harmful organisms or on plants, parts of plants or plant products, referred to as ‘active substances’. It aims to create uniform patent protection throughout the EU.
