Preservation of bank accounts Preservation of bank accounts SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1215/2012 — preservation of bank accounts WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to establish a uniform European procedure for the preservation of bank accounts. It aims to prevent the subsequent enforcement of a debtor’s claim against the debtor from being jeopardised through the transfer or withdrawal of funds up to the amount specified in the order. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to pecuniary claims in civil and commercial matters in cross-border cases as defined in Article 3, whatever the nature of the court or tribunal concerned (the ‘court’). It does not apply to: rights in property arising out of a matrimonial relationship or out of a relationship deemed by the law applicable to such relationship to have comparable effects to marriage; wills and succession, including maintenance obligations arising by reason of death; claims against a debtor in relation to whom bankruptcy proceedings, proceedings for the winding-up of insolvent companies or other legal persons, judicial arrangements, compositions, or analogous proceedings have been opened; social security; arbitration. The regulation does not apply to: rights in property arising out of a matrimonial relationship or out of a relationship deemed by the law applicable to such relationship to have comparable effects to marriage; wills and succession, including maintenance obligations arising by reason of death; claims against a debtor in relation to whom bankruptcy proceedings, proceedings for the winding-up of insolvent companies or other legal persons, judicial arrangements, compositions, or analogous proceedings have been opened; social security; arbitration. Border surveillance at sea Border surveillance at sea SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1052/2013 — surveillance of the sea external borders in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure the safety of persons in distress at sea and to ensure that the EU’s border surveillance system (Eurosur) is effective in preventing and discouraging unauthorised border crossings, to counter cross-border criminality and to avoid loss of life at sea. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to border surveillance operations carried out by EU countries at their external sea borders in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (‘the Agency’). The regulation lays down rules for the surveillance of the sea borders by border guards operating under the coordination of the Agency. The regulation also lays down rules for the operation of the European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur) and for the operation of the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). The regulation also lays down rules for the operation of the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). The regulation also lays down rules for the operation of the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). The regulation also lays down rules for the operation of the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 18 July 2015. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Border surveillance (European Commission). KEY TERMS Search and rescue: a situation where it is necessary to rescue a person in distress at sea. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) No 1052/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 October 2013 establishing the European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur) (OJ L 295, 6.11.2013, pp. 11–17). Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) No 1052/2013 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. It establishes the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) for the period 2014-2020. EU border surveillance system (EUROSUR) EU border surveillance system (EUROSUR) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1052/2013 establishing the European Border Surveillance System (EUROSUR) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Border Surveillance System (EUROSUR) to improve the situational awareness and reaction capability of EU countries’ national authorities at the external borders of the EU. It aims to improve the operational and technical ability of the EU countries to detect small and unseaworthy vessels and to improve the reaction capability of the EU countries. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes the European Border Surveillance System (EUROSUR) which aims to improve the situational awareness and reaction capability of EU countries’ national authorities at the external borders of the EU. It aims to improve the operational and technical ability of the EU countries to detect small and unseaworthy vessels and to improve the reaction capability of the EU countries. It also aims to improve the exchange of information and cooperation with other EU bodies, offices and agencies, such as the European Maritime Safety Agency and the European Union Satellite Centre. Single-hull oil tankers Single-hull oil tankers SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 73/78 — application of the double-hull or equivalent design requirements to single-hull oil tankers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that oil tankers of 5 000 tonnes deadweight and above can enter into ports and offshore terminals under the jurisdiction of EU countries. It also bans the transport to or from ports of the EU countries of heavy grade oil in single-hull oil tankers. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to oil tankers of 5 000 tonnes deadweight and above: which fly the flag of a EU country; irrespective of their flag, which enter or leave a port or offshore terminal or anchor in an area under the jurisdiction of a EU country. For the purposes of this regulation, the regulation applies to oil tankers of 600 tonnes deadweight and above. Freedom of movement for workers Freedom of movement for workers SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1151/2011 — freedom of movement for workers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that all EU citizens have the right to take up an activity as an employed person, and to pursue such activity within the EU. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to all EU citizens, irrespective of their place of residence. The right to take up an activity as an employed person is guaranteed by the EU’s constitution. Any national of a EU country and any employer pursuing an activity in the territory of another EU country may exchange their applications for and offers of employment, and may conclude and perform contracts of employment in accordance with the provisions in force. The regulation does not apply: where they limit application for and offers of employment, or the right of foreign nationals to take up and pursue employment or subject these to conditions not applicable in respect of their own nationals; where, though applicable irrespective of nationality, their exclusive or principal aim or effect is to keep nationals of other EU countries away from the employment offered. The regulation does not apply: where they limit application for and offers of employment, or the right of foreign nationals to take up and pursue employment or subject these to conditions not applicable in respect of their own nationals; where, though applicable irrespective of nationality, their exclusive or principal aim or effect is to keep nationals of other EU countries away from the employment offered. Controlled substances: reporting obligations Controlled substances: reporting obligations SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1272/2008 on substances that deplete the ozone layer WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules on the production, import, export, placing on the market, use, recovery, recycling, reclamation and destruction of substances that deplete the ozone layer. It aims to protect the ozone layer and reduce greenhouse gases emissions. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to: controlled substances, new substances and products and equipment containing or relying on those substances. It prohibits the production, import, export, placing on the market, use, recovery, recycling, reclamation and destruction of substances that deplete the ozone layer. It also prohibits the placing on the market and the use of controlled substances in non-refillable containers, except for laboratory and analytical uses. Summary 112:
European Environment Agency European Environment Agency SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1210/90 — setting up a European Environment Information and Observation Network WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up a European Environment Information and Observation Network (EINN) to collect, collate and analyse environmental data. It is based in Brussels and is headed by an Executive Director. KEY POINTS EINN is a network of national environmental information centres, based in Brussels, which collect, collate and analyse environmental data. The EINN is responsible for collecting, collating and analysing data on air quality, water quality, pollutants and water resources, the state of the soil, fauna and flora and biotopes, land use and natural resources, waste management, noise emissions, chemical substances which are hazardous for the environment, coastal and marine protection. EINN is a multiannual work programme based on the priority areas of work: air quality and atmospheric emissions; water quality, pollutants and water resources; the state of the soil, of the fauna and flora and of biotopes; land use and natural resources; waste management; noise emissions; chemical substances which are hazardous for the environment; coastal and marine protection. EINN is headed by an Executive Director appointed by the Management Board on a proposal from the Commission for a period of 5 years, which shall be renewable once. Civil aviation security Civil aviation security SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 961/2008 establishing common rules in the field of civil aviation security WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out common rules and common basic standards on aviation security. It also provides the basis for a common interpretation of Annex 17 to the Chicago Convention on International Civil Aviation. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to all airports or parts of airports located in the territory of a Member State that are not exclusively used for military purposes. It aims to freeze funds and economic resources belonging to, owned, held or controlled by any person, entity or body, including: State actors; other actors exercising effective control or authority over a territory; other non-State actors. EU military operation in the Mediterranean EU military operation in the Mediterranean SUMMARY OF: Decision (CFSP) 2020/472 on a European Union military operation in the Southern Central Mediterranean WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It establishes and launches a military crisis management operation to contribute to preventing arms trafficking within its agreed Area of Operation and Area of Interest in accordance with UNSCR 1970 (2011) and subsequent Resolutions on the arms embargo on Libya, including UNSCR 2292 (2016) and UNSCR 2473 (2019). The operation is named EUNAVFOR MED IRINI. It contributes to the implementation of UN measures to prevent the illicit export of petroleum from Libya, in particular UNSCR 2146 (2014) and subsequent Resolutions, in particular UNSCR 2509 (2020) and UNSCR 2510 (2020). The operation is also a secondary task, and within its means and capabilities, it conducts monitoring and surveillance activities and gathers information on illicit exports from Libya of petroleum, including crude oil and refined petroleum products, which are contrary to UNSCR 2146 (2014) and subsequent Resolutions, in particular UNSCR 2509 (2020) and UNSCR 2510 (2020). European Image Archiving System (FADO) European Image Archiving System (FADO) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2020/1726 — the European Union Agency for the Operational Management of Large-Scale IT Systems in the Area of Freedom, Security and Justice (eu-LISA) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up a European Image Archiving System (FADO) to facilitate the exchange of information on authentic and false documents between EU countries. It also provides for the electronic storage, rapid exchange and validation of information on authentic and false documents. KEY POINTS The FADO system contains information on travel, identity, residence and civil status documents, driving licences and vehicle licences issued by EU countries or the EU, and on false versions thereof. The FADO system also contains information on other related official documents, such as those used in support of applications for official documents, issued by EU countries and, where applicable, third parties, such as third countries, territorial entities, international organisations and other entities subject to international law, and on false versions thereof. The FADO system is based on the EU’s Authentic Documents Online (ADO) system. The FADO system is a tool for the fight against document and identity fraud. It provides for the electronic storage, rapid exchange and validation of information on authentic and false documents. The FADO system is based on the EU’s Authentic Documents Online (ADO) system. The FADO system is based on the EU’s Authentic Documents Online (ADO) system. The FADO system is based on the EU’s Authentic Documents Online (ADO) system. Summary 119:
Prohibition of access to certain professions Prohibition of access to certain professions SUMMARY OF: Directive 2018/36/EU on the regulation of certain professions WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to ensure that EU countries are able to regulate certain professions within the limits of the principles of non-discrimination and proportionality. It aims to ensure that the rules regulating certain professions are not disproportionate and that they do not affect the EU’s competence. KEY POINTS EU countries must assess the proportionality of their new or amended rules before introducing new, or amending existing, rules restricting access to, or the pursuit of, a regulated profession. The extent of the assessment must be proportionate to the nature, content and impact of the provision. The reasons for considering that a provision is justified and proportionate must be substantiated by qualitative and, wherever possible and relevant, quantitative elements. The EU countries must monitor the compliance of new or amended rules with the principle of proportionality. The EU countries must also make information available to citizens, service recipients and other relevant stakeholders before introducing new, or amending existing, rules restricting access to, or the pursuit of, a regulated profession. The EU countries must also encourage the exchange of information between EU countries on matters covered by this directive and on the particular way that they regulate a profession, or on the effects of such regulation. FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY? It has applied since 30 July 2018. EU countries had to incorporate it into national law by 30 July 2020. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Prohibition of access to certain professions (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Directive 2018/36/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 7 September 2018 on the regulation of certain professions (OJ L 255, 30.9.2005, pp. 22–24). Successive amendments to Directive 2018/36/EU have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Multiannual plan for demersal stocks Multiannual plan for demersal stocks SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013 — multiannual plan for demersal stocks WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a multiannual plan for demersal stocks in the EU’s North Sea (ICES divisions 2a, 3a and subareas 2a, 3a and subareas 4 and 5). It aims to achieve the objectives of the common fisheries policy (CFP) and to ensure that exploitation of living marine biological resources restores and maintains populations of harvested species above levels which can produce MSY as determined by their biological characteristics. KEY POINTS The plan aims to: achieve the objectives of the CFP; apply the precautionary approach to fisheries management; implement the ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management; minimise the negative impacts of fishing activities on the marine ecosystem; contribute to the achievement of good environmental status by 2020. The plan also aims to: eliminate discards; reduce unwanted catches; implement the landing obligation for demersal stocks subject to catch limits; promote a fair standard of living for those who depend on fishing activities, bearing in mind coastal fisheries and socioeconomic aspects; implement the ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management. The plan also aims to: ensure that the conditions described in descriptor 3 contained in Annex I to Directive 2008/56/EC are fulfilled; contribute to the fulfilment of other relevant descriptors contained in Annex I to Directive 2008/56/EC in proportion to the role played by fisheries in their fulfilment. It lays down management, conservation and control measures relating to fishing for straddling fish stocks in the South Pacific Ocean (SPRFMO). It lays down the rules for issuing and managing fishing authorisations for EU fishing vessels conducting fishing operations in waters under the auspices of a regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO). Controls of cash entering or leaving the EU Controls of cash entering or leaving the EU SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/1796 — controls of cash entering or leaving the EU WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to prevent and detect money laundering and terrorist financing by laying down a system of controls applicable to natural persons who enter or leave the EU carrying amounts of cash or bearer-negotiable instruments equal to or greater than EUR 10 000 or its equivalent in other currencies. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to natural persons entering or leaving the EU carrying amounts of cash or bearer-negotiable instruments equal to or greater than EUR 10 000 or its equivalent in other currencies. The regulation does not affect the ability of EU countries to provide additional national controls on movements of cash within the EU, provided that those controls are in accordance with the EU’s fundamental freedoms, in particular Articles 63 and 65 TFEU. The regulation does not affect the ability of EU countries to provide, under their national law, for additional national controls on movements of cash within the EU, provided that those controls are in accordance with the EU’s fundamental freedoms, in particular Articles 63 and 65 TFEU. Energy Union: integrated national energy and climate plans Energy Union: integrated national energy and climate plans SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 525/2013 on integrated national energy and climate plans WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the framework for EU countries to prepare integrated national energy and climate plans. These are based on the EU’s commitment to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by at least 40% by 2021 and by at least 30% by 2022. The regulation sets out the structure and format for the plans, which must be submitted by EU countries by 30 June 2024 and every 10 years thereafter. The plans must cover the period from 2021 to 2030, taking into account the longer term perspective. The plans must: limit administrative complexity and costs for all relevant stakeholders; take into account the interlinkages between the five dimensions of the Energy Union, in particular the energy efficiency first principle; use robust and, where appropriate, a national indicative objective to reduce energy poverty. The plans must also include: a national indicative objective to reduce energy poverty; a macroeconomic and, to the extent feasible, the health, environmental, skills and social impact of the plans and measures; a proposal for a Union long-term strategy for greenhouse gas emissions reduction in accordance with the Paris Agreement. The Commission must assess the draft plans and may issue country-specific recommendations to EU countries in accordance with the regulation. The Commission must assess the draft plans and may issue country-specific recommendations to EU countries in accordance with the regulation. Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/96 — implementing the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to protect human health and the environment from the continuous release of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) into the environment. The regulation aims to: ban the manufacturing, placing on the market and use of intentionally manufactured POPs; restrict exemptions to a minimum so that exemptions only apply where a substance fulfils an essential function in a specific application; promote and facilitate the use of POPs to those whose health and safety are threatened; ensure that the POP content is destroyed or irreversibly transformed so that the remaining waste and releases do not exhibit the characteristics of POPs. KEY POINTS The regulation prohibits the manufacturing, placing on the market and use of intentionally manufactured POPs. Single-use plastic products Single-use plastic products SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/883 on single-use plastic products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to reduce the quantity of plastic waste in the EU by establishing a specific legal framework to effectively reduce the negative environmental, health and economic impact of certain plastic products. KEY POINTS Scope The directive covers: single-use plastic products (i.e. products that are conceived, designed and placed on the market to accomplish within their life span multiple trips or rotations by being refilled or re-used for the same purpose for which they are conceived). The directive covers: food containers; beverage containers; caps and lids made of plastic used for beverage containers; tobacco products with filters containing plastic; wet wipes; balloons; lightweight plastic carrier bags; sanitary towels (pads), tampons and tampon applicators. The directive also covers: extended producer responsibility schemes for all single-use plastic products listed in Part E of the directive; harmonised specifications for the marking of single-use plastic products; information systems and reporting. The directive requires EU countries to: monitor the single-use plastic products listed in Part A of the directive; set a national minimum annual collection rate of waste fishing gear containing plastic for recycling; EU consumer protection rules EU consumer protection rules SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/1128 — rules for the coordination of investigation and enforcement measures relating to widespread infringements and widespread infringements with a Union dimension WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the effectiveness of EU consumer protection laws by establishing a network of competent public enforcement authorities throughout the EU. It aims to ensure that the EU’s consumer protection laws are enforced effectively and efficiently. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the minimum investigation and enforcement powers of EU national authorities. These powers include: — the power to impose fines or periodic penalty payments on the trader responsible for the infringement; — the power to impose interim measures to check compliance with, or to detect, infringements of EU laws that protect consumers’ interests. The regulation also sets out the procedures for the coordination of investigation and enforcement measures relating to widespread infringements and widespread infringements with a Union dimension. The regulation does not apply to intra-EU infringements of Directives 2014/17/EU and 2014/92/EU. The regulation does not apply to intra-EU infringements of Directives 2014/17/EU and 2014/92/EU. The regulation does not apply to intra-EU infringements of Directives 2014/17/EU and 2014/92/EU. The regulation does not apply to intra-EU infringements of Directives 2014/17/EU and 2014/92/EU. The regulation does not apply to intra-EU infringements of Directives 2014/17/EU and 2014/92/EU. The regulation does not apply to intra-EU infringements of Directives 2014/17/EU and 2014/92/EU. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 17 January 2020. EU countries had to incorporate it into national law by 17 January 2020. It aims to ensure the smooth functioning of the EU’s internal market as regards in vitro diagnostic medical devices. Summary 130:
EU gas safety rules: appliances and fittings EU gas safety rules: appliances and fittings SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 882/2014 — gas safety rules for appliances and fittings WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that appliances and fittings comply with EU gas safety rules. It repeals Directive 2009/142/EC, which lays down rules on appliances burning gaseous fuels. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to appliances and fittings intended for a number of specified applications and to fittings designed to be incorporated into such appliances. It does not apply to appliances covered by a measure adopted pursuant to Directive 2009/125/EC. Manufacturers must draw up an EU declaration of conformity and affix the CE marking. Before placing an appliance on the market, manufacturers must carry out a conformity assessment and ensure that procedures are in place for series production to remain in conformity with this regulation. Importers must indicate on the appliance their name, registered trade name or registered trade mark and the postal address at which they can be contacted or, where that is not possible, on the packaging or in a document accompanying the appliance. Distributors must ensure that, while an appliance is under their responsibility, storage or transport conditions do not jeopardise its compliance with the essential requirements set out in Annex I. They must also inform the competent national authorities of any non-compliance and of any corrective measures taken. They must also keep a register of complaints, of non-conforming appliances and fittings and recalls of such appliances and fittings. They must also keep distributors informed of any monitoring. The regulation also sets out the rules for notified bodies, which are responsible for assessing and ensuring that appliances and fittings comply with the essential requirements. The regulation also sets out the rules for notified bodies, which are responsible for assessing and ensuring that appliances and fittings comply with the essential requirements. Food information — labelling Food information — labelling SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 on the provision of food information to consumers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out rules for the labelling of foods, ensuring that consumers are informed of the ingredients and nutritional characteristics of the food they consume. It also sets out rules for the presentation of foods, in particular their shape, appearance or packaging, the packaging materials used, the way in which they are arranged and the setting in which they are displayed. KEY POINTS The regulation covers: the identity and composition, properties or other characteristics of the food; the protection of consumers’ health and the safe use of a food; information on nutritional characteristics so as to enable consumers, including those with special dietary requirements, to make informed choices. The regulation also covers: the country of origin or place of provenance of a food; the list of ingredients; the expression of the net quantity; the country of origin or place of provenance of certain substances or products causing allergies or intolerances; It sets out the missions of the European Social Fund (ESF), including the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI), the scope of its support, specific provisions and the types of expenditure eligible for assistance. KEY POINTS The ESF supports the following investment priorities: promoting sustainable and capacity building for all stakeholders delivering education, lifelong learning, training and employment and social policies; supporting the design and implementation of policies and actions in connection with its missions; supporting the implementation of reforms, in particular in the fields of employment, education, training and social policies. The ESF also supports the following investment priorities: promoting social inclusion, combating poverty and any discrimination; promoting equal opportunities and non-discrimination; promoting social innovation within all areas falling under its scope; promoting sustainable urban development through strategies setting out integrated actions to tackle the economic, environmental and social challenges affecting the urban areas identified by the Member States on the basis of the principles laid down in their respective Partnership Agreements. Demographic statistics: common legal framework Demographic statistics: common legal framework SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 961/2013 — common legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of European statistics on population and vital events WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a common legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of European statistics on population and vital events. KEY POINTS The regulation defines the following persons as usual residents of a specific geographical area: those who have lived in their place of usual residence for a continuous period of at least 12 relatives, business, medical treatment or religious pilgrimage. The following persons alone are considered to be usual residents of a specific geographical area: those who have lived in their place of usual residence for a continuous period of at least 12 months before the reference time; or those who arrived in their place of usual residence during the 12 months before the reference time with the intention of staying there for at least one year. The data provided must cover the following variables: live births by sex, month of occurrence, live birth-order, mother’s age, mother’s year of birth, mother’s country of birth, mother’s country of citizenship and mother’s region of residence; deaths by age, sex, year of birth, region of residence, country of birth, country of citizenship and month of occurrence. The Commission adopts implementing acts laying down uniform conditions for the breakdown of data for deadlines and for revisions of data. Key investor information document Key investor information document SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 962/2014 on key investor information documents WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down uniform rules on the format and content of the key investor information document to be drawn up by PRIIP manufacturers and on the provision of the key information document to retail investors in order to enable retail investors to understand and compare the key features and risks of the PRIIP. It lays down uniform rules on the format and content of the key investor information document to be drawn up by PRIIP manufacturers and on the provision of the key information document to retail investors in order to enable retail investors to understand and compare the key features and risks of the PRIIP. KEY TERMS Key information document: a document that provides key information about the investment product. It must be written in a concise manner and of a maximum of three sides of A4-sized paper when printed, which promotes comparability. It must contain the following information: at the beginning of the document, the name of the PRIIP, the identity and contact details of the PRIIP manufacturer, information about the competent authority of the PRIIP manufacturer and the date of the document; where applicable, a comprehension alert which reads: ‘You are about to purchase a product that is not simple and may be difficult to understand.’; under a section titled ‘What is this product?’, the nature and main features of the PRIIP, including: the type of the PRIIP, its objectives and the means for achieving them, in particular whether the objectives are achieved by means of direct or indirect exposure to the underlying investment assets, including a description of the underlying instruments or reference values, including a specification of the markets the PRIIP invests in, including, where applicable, specific environmental or social objectives targeted by the product, as well as how the return is determined; a brief description of whether the related loss is covered by an investor compensation or guarantee scheme and if so, which scheme it is, the name of the guarantor and which risks are covered by the scheme and which are not; under a section titled ‘Other relevant information’, a brief indication of any additional information documents to be provided to the retail investor at the pre-contractual and/or the post-contractual stage, excluding any marketing material. The key information document must be written in the official languages, or in one of the official languages, used in the part of the EU where the PRIIP is distributed, or in another language accepted by the competent authorities of that EU country, or where it has been written in a different language, it must be translated into one of these languages. The key information document must be written in the official languages, or in one of the official languages, used in the part of the EU where the PRIIP is distributed, or in another language accepted by the competent authorities of that EU country, or where it has been written in a different language, it must be translated into one of these languages. It lays down rules for the establishment and organisation of international rail freight corridors with a view to the development of a European rail network for competitive freight. Summary 147:
Job vacancy statistics Job vacancy statistics SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 962/2008 on job vacancy statistics WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the requirements for the regular quarterly production of statistics on job vacancies. It aims to ensure that the data provided are relevant and complete, accurate and comprehensive, timely, coherent, comparable and readily accessible to users. KEY POINTS Each EU country must submit to Eurostat data on job vacancies at least for business units with one employee or more. The data must cover all economic activities defined by the common classification system for economic activities in the EU (NACE). The data must be broken down by economic activity in accordance with the NACE in force. The data must distinguish, on an optional basis, between vacancies for fixed-term and permanent jobs. The data must be provided using business surveys. EU countries may supplement the sources of all data provided with reliable statistical estimation procedures. EU countries must transmit the data and metadata to Eurostat in a format and within transmission deadlines. The data must be delivered no later than on the date of the first data transmission and the breakdowns no more than one year thereafter. EU countries may take part in sample schemes when such schemes create possibilities for substantial reductions in the cost of the statistical systems or the burden on business entailed in meeting the EU requirement. EU countries must submit reports on the quality of the data transmitted to Eurostat within 12 months of the entry into force of the Commission implementing measures. The Commission must submit a report to the European Parliament and the Council on the implementation of this regulation every 3 years. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 24 June 2008. BACKGROUND For more information, see: ‘Job vacancy statistics’ on the European Commission’s website. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EC) No 962/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 June 2008 on job vacancy statistics (OJ L 96, 26.5.2008, pp. 1-2) Successive amendments to Regulation (EC) No 962/2008 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. RELATED DOCUMENTS Report from the Commission to the European Parliament and the Council on the implementation of Regulation (EC) No 962/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of Regulation (EC) No 962/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council on job vacancy statistics (COM(2014) 96 final, 21.5.2014) Commission Decision No 1672/2006/EC of 24 October 2006 establishing a Community Programme for Employment and Social Solidarity — Progress (COM(2014) 96 final, 21.5.2006) last update 04.02.2019

Statistics on migration and asylum Statistics on migration and asylum SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 962/2007 — common rules for the collection and compilation of Community statistics on migration and asylum WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that the European Union (EU) collects and compiles statistics on migration and asylum. It aims to ensure that the European Union (EU) collects and compiles statistics on migration and asylum. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out common rules for the collection and compilation of statistics on: immigration to and emigration from the EU territories, including flows from the territory of one EU country to that of another EU country and EU countries must report to the Commission (Eurostat) on the use and probable effects of estimations or other methods of adapting statistics based on national definitions to comply with the harmonised definitions set out in the regulation. The statistics supplied to the Commission (Eurostat) are based on the following data sources according to their availability in the EU and in accordance with national laws and practices: records of administrative and judicial actions; registers relating to administrative actions; registers of the population of persons or of a particular sub-group of that population; censuses; sample surveys; other appropriate sources. The regulation does not cover estimates of the number of persons illegally resident in the EU. EU countries must supply to the Commission (Eurostat) statistics on: the numbers of: third-country nationals refused entry to the EU’s territory at the external border; third-country nationals found to be illegally present in the EU’s territory under national laws relating to immigration. The statistics on the prevention of illegal entry and stay are disaggregated by age and sex, and by citizenship of the persons concerned. The statistics on residence permits and residence of third-country nationals are disaggregated by age and sex, and by citizenship of the persons concerned. Conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine biological resources Conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine biological resources SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1379/2013 on the conservation and sustainable exploitation of fisheries resources WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that the EU’s fisheries policy is compatible with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). It aims to protect marine biological resources and the management of fisheries targeting them. KEY POINTS The regulation covers the following activities: fishing on the territory of EU countries to which the Treaty applies; fishing in EU waters, including by fishing vessels flying the flag of, and registered in, third countries; by Union fishing vessels outside EU waters; or by nationals of EU countries without prejudice to the primary responsibility of the flag state. Securities settlement systems Securities settlement systems SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 909/2014 — uniform rules for securities settlement systems WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down uniform rules for securities settlement systems (CSDs)*. These are central securities depositories* (CSDs)* and central securities accounts maintenance services* (CSAPs). These are important tools to control the integrity of an issue, hindering the undue creation or reduction of issued securities and thereby play an important role in maintaining investor confidence. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to all securities settlement systems*, including: book-entry forms; settlement periods; penalties; internalised settlement; links between CSDs; access to CSDs and other market infrastructures; Cohesion Fund Cohesion Fund SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 establishing a Cohesion Fund WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Cohesion Fund (CF) to support the Investment for growth and jobs goal set out in Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013. KEY POINTS The CF supports: investment in the environment, including areas related to sustainable development and energy which present environmental benefits; TEN-T, in compliance with the guidelines adopted by Regulation (EU) No 1315/2013; technical assistance. The CF does not support: the decommissioning or the construction of nuclear power stations; investment to achieve the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions; investment to achieve the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from activities listed in Annex I to Directive 2003/87/EC. Trans-European energy infrastructure: guidelines for the timely development and interoperability Trans-European energy infrastructure: guidelines for the timely development and interoperability SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 347/2013 on guidelines for trans-European energy infrastructure WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down guidelines for the timely development and interoperability of priority corridors and areas of trans-European energy infrastructure. These priority corridors and areas cover different geographic regions or thematic areas in the field of electricity transmission and storage, gas transmission, storage and liquefied or compressed natural gas infrastructure, smart grids, electricity highways, carbon dioxide transport and oil infrastructure. The regulation establishes twelve regional groups (Regional Groups) to ensure cross-regional consistency, taking into account the opinion of the European Agency for Energy (EACE) and aiming for a manageable total number of projects of common interest on the Union list. Online dispute resolution (ODR) Online dispute resolution (ODR) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 524/2013 on online dispute resolution for consumer disputes WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to create an online dispute resolution (ODR) platform for consumers and traders seeking to resolve disputes arising from online sales and service contracts. It aims to improve the availability, quality and awareness of simple, efficient, fast and low-cost ways of resolving disputes arising from online transactions. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to the out-of-court resolution of disputes concerning contractual obligations stemming from online sales or service contracts between a consumer resident in the EU and a trader established in the EU through the intervention of an ADR entity listed in accordance with Article 20(2) of out-of-court resolution of disputes concerning contractual obligations stemming from online sales or service contracts between a consumer resident in the EU and a trader established in the EU through the intervention of an ADR entity listed in accordance with Article 20(2) of Directive 2013/11/EU and which involves the use of the ODR platform. The regulation establishes a single point of entry for consumers and traders seeking to resolve disputes arising from online transactions. It provides general information regarding the out-of-court resolution of contractual obligations stemming from online sales or service contracts between a consumer resident in the EU and a trader established in the EU through the intervention of an ADR entity listed in accordance with Article 20(2) of out-of-court resolution of disputes concerning contractual obligations stemming from online sales or service contracts between a consumer resident in the EU and a trader established in the EU through the intervention of an ADR entity listed in accordance with Article 20(2) of Directive 2013/11/EU and which involves the use of the ODR platform. The regulation establishes a network of ODR contact points which provide support to the resolution of disputes relating to complaints submitted through the ODR platform by fulfilling the following functions: if requested, facilitating communication between the parties and the competent ADR entity, which may include, in particular: assisting with the submission of the complaint and, where appropriate, relevant documentation; if necessary, ensuring that the complaint is processed and transmitted to the ADR entity that the parties have agreed to use. The Commission must establish and maintain an electronic database in which it stores the information processed under this regulation. The Commission must report to the European Parliament and the Council on the functioning of the ODR platform on a yearly basis and for the first time one year after the ODR platform has become operational. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 9 January 2016. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Online dispute resolution (European Commission). KEY TERMS Online sales or service contract: a contract where the trader, or the trader’s intermediary, has offered goods or services through a website or by other electronic means and the consumer has ordered those goods or services on that website or by other electronic means. It aims to improve and expedite the transmission of judicial and extrajudicial documents between EU countries. It does not extend in particular to revenue, customs or administrative matters or to liability of the State for actions or omissions in the exercise of state authority (acta iure imperii). Emissions from motor vehicles Emissions from motor vehicles SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 — technical requirements for the type approval of motor vehicles and replacement parts, such as replacement pollution control devices, with regard to their emissions WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down common technical requirements for the type approval of motor vehicles and replacement parts, such as replacement pollution control devices, with regard to their emissions. It also lays down rules for access to vehicle repair and maintenance information. KEY POINTS Manufacturers must demonstrate that all new vehicles sold, registered or put into service in the EU are type approved in accordance with this regulation and its implementing measures. Manufacturers must also demonstrate that all new replacement pollution control devices requiring type approval which are sold or put into service in the EU are type approved in accordance with this regulation and its implementing measures. Manufacturers must equip vehicles so that the components likely to affect emissions are designed, constructed and assembled so as to enable the vehicle, in normal use, to comply with this regulation and its implementing measures. Manufacturers must charge reasonable and proportionate fees for access to vehicle repair and maintenance information. Manufacturers must make available vehicle repair and maintenance information on a daily, monthly, and yearly basis, with fees for access varying in accordance with the respective periods of time for which access is granted. Accreditation and market surveillance Accreditation and market surveillance SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 962/2008 — rules on accreditation, market surveillance, controls of products from non-EU countries and the CE marking WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules on the organisation and operation of accreditation and market surveillance* of products. It aims to ensure that those products fulfil requirements providing a high level of protection of public interests, such as health and safety in general, health and safety at the workplace, the protection of consumers, protection of the environment and security. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the rules on the organisation and operation of accreditation and market surveillance* of products. It lays down the general principles of the CE marking. It is the only marking of conformity indicating that a product is in conformity with the applicable requirements set out in Community harmonisation legislation. It does not apply in the areas covered by specific legislation. The regulation also lays down the general principles of the CE marking. Arrest warrant agreement between the EU and Norway Arrest warrant agreement between the EU and Norway SUMMARY OF: Agreement on extradition between the EU and Norway Decision (EU) 2017/1709 on the conclusion of the Agreement on extradition between the EU and Norway Decision (EU) 2017/1709 on the conclusion of the Agreement on extradition between the EU and Norway WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE AGREEMENT AND OF THE DECISION? The agreement aims to improve the extradition system between the EU and Norway by ensuring that the extradition system between the EU and Norway is based on a mechanism of surrender pursuant to an arrest warrant. KEY POINTS The agreement applies to all EU countries, except Iceland and Norway, which have uniform extradition laws with a common concept of extradition. The agreement does not have the effect of modifying the obligation to respect fundamental rights and fundamental legal principles as enshrined in the European Convention on Human Rights, or, in case of execution by the judicial authority of a Member State, of the principles referred to in the Treaty on European Union. Passengers’ rights on rail passenger services Passengers’ rights on rail passenger services SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 96/2007 — rules on the rights of passengers on rail passenger services WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve rail passenger services in the European Union (EU). It aims to protect passengers’ rights in the event of delays, missed connections or cancellations. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to all rail journeys and services throughout the EU provided by one or more railway undertakings licensed in accordance with Council Directive 95/18/EC of 19 June 1995 on the licensing of railway undertakings. Rights of passengers in bus and coach transport Rights of passengers in bus and coach transport SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 181/2011 on the rights of passengers in bus and coach transport WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that passengers in bus and coach transport have the same rights as other citizens. It aims to ensure that passengers have the same rights as other citizens. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to passengers travelling with regular services for non-specified categories of passengers where the boarding or the alighting point of the passengers is situated in the territory of a Member State and where the scheduled distance of the service is 250 km or more. Summary 174:
Aquaculture statistics EU countries must submit to the European Commission statistics on all the aquaculture activities conducted in freshwater and saltwaters on their territory. ACT Regulation (EC) No 1082/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 July 2008 on Community statistics on aquaculture activities conducted in freshwater and saltwaters on their territory. SUMMARY The regulation establishes a common legal framework for the collection and submission of statistics on all the aquaculture activities conducted in freshwater and saltwaters on their territory. It aims to ensure that the EU’s fisheries policy is properly managed. KEY POINTS EU countries must submit to the European Commission statistics on all the aquaculture activities conducted in freshwater and saltwaters on their territory. The data cover: the annual production (volume and unit value) of aquaculture; the annual input (volume and unit value) to capture-based aquaculture; the annual production of hatcheries and nurseries; the structure of the aquaculture sector. EU countries must provide the Commission with a yearly report on the quality of the data submitted. The Commission must examine the reports and present its conclusions to the relevant working group of the Standing Committee for Agricultural Statistics set up by Decision 72/279/EEC. EU countries must support any request for derogations, which must be made prior to the deadline for the first submission of the data, by sending the Commission a report on problems encountered in applying this regulation. The Commission must submit an evaluation report to the European Parliament and to the Council on the statistics compiled pursuant to this regulation and, in particular, on their relevance and quality. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2009. EU countries had to incorporate it into national law by 1 January 2009. BACKGROUND For more information, see: ‘Aquaculture statistics’ on the European Commission's website. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EC) No 1082/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 July 2008 on Community statistics on aquaculture activities conducted in freshwater and saltwaters on their territory (OJ L 202, 21.7.2008, pp. 1-2) Successive amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1082/2008 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. EU scheme of control and enforcement in the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Scheme of control and enforcement in the North-East Atlantic Fisheries SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1142/2010 — rules for the application of the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Scheme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the general rules and conditions for the application by the European Union (EU) of the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Scheme (NEAFC). KEY POINTS EU countries must send to the European Commission, in a computer-readable form, a list of all vessels flying their flag and registered in the EU which are authorised to fish in the Regulatory Area, in particular the vessels authorised to fish directly for one or more regulated resources together with any amendments to the list. Supplementary protection certificates Supplementary protection certificates SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 962/2009 — supplementary protection certificates WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to provide a uniform system for granting supplementary protection certificates to the holder of a basic patent for a medicinal product for which marketing authorisation has been granted. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to supplementary protection certificates granted in accordance with the national legislation of the Czech Republic, Estonia, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovenia and Slovakia prior to 1 May 2004 and the national legislation of Romania prior to 1 January 2007. Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters SUMMARY OF: Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters Decision (EU) 2017/1709 on the conclusion of the Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE CONVENTION AND OF THE DECISION? The convention aims to ensure that EU countries’ courts and courts of justice have exclusive jurisdiction in all civil and commercial matters. It does not apply to: the status or legal capacity of natural persons, rights in property arising out of a matrimonial relationship, wills and succession; bankruptcy, proceedings relating to the winding-up of insolvent companies or other legal persons, judicial arrangements, compositions and analogous proceedings; social security; arbitration. KEY POINTS The convention applies to: civil and commercial matters whatever the nature of the court or tribunal; revenue, customs or administrative matters; the status or legal capacity of natural persons, rights in property arising out of a matrimonial relationship, wills and succession; bankruptcy, proceedings relating to the winding-up of insolvent companies or other legal persons, judicial arrangements, compositions and analogous proceedings; social security; arbitration.
